Arts in depth

"What do you mean he doesn't do email?" - Sarah Bolwell explores the work of the elusive painter Douglas Binder as preparation gets underway for his new exhibition in York next month

Up and coming events

This November, internationally renowned artist Rob Ryan opens an exciting major exhibition of new paper cuts and screen prints. Displaying the whimsical beauty that we have all come to know and love, these new works capture the distinctive qualities of the evocative hand-crafted paper cut, drawing the viewer into Ryan's world of romance (Thumbnail credit Rob Ryan, Your Job, original papercut, courtesy of TAG Fine Arts)

Chalices of the Past

By James Bithell

Tom Killingbeck confronts York's furtive electro-warlock Chalices of the Past

Future Sounds

In some unintentionally brilliant timing, the few bands in this week's Future Sounds have all been described as part of a movement called 'Witch House' (Thumbnail credit Salem)

Scentless Apprentices

A grunge revival? Japanese Voyeurs tell Estella Adeyeri what it's all about

Martin Simpson

Martin Simpson holds what must be the record for most BBC Radio 2 Folk Award nominations, but tonight there's no sense of superiority or self-importance, either while he's onstage or when wandering through the small crowd here beforehand and afterwards

Port-Royal

Ambient music is not one of genres that you would ever tip to go 'big'. Bands like Boards of Canada and Stars of the Lid don't often find themselves filling arenas or headlining Dronefest '10

Nouse Playlist

While you're popping razorblades in bobbing apples or throwing bags of fiery turd at lecturers' houses in fervent celebration of witches' night, perhaps fill up your iPod with these evil cuts from beyond the rave

The Social Network

If asked to describe David Fincher's directorial style, one word that constantly springs to mind is ambitious. Never one to shy away from a challenging storyline, here he tries his hand at dissecting the petty playground politics of Facebook's founders and the subsequent struggle for power in <em>The Social Network</em>

Despicable Me

Let's get this out of the way: I cried at this film. That's not saying much, admittedly, considering you're reading the words of someone who cried at <em>Cool Runnings</em>, but then that same person is one of the few who believes that <em>Cool Runnings</em> is a masterpiece of modern cinema

Come and See (1985)

Critically acclaimed upon its release, and clocking over 25 million admissions in the Soviet Union alone, <em>Come and See</em> is the tale of a child soldier, Florya, and his fight for survival in Nazi occupied Belaru

Temptation and Taqwacores at this year's London Film Festival

Terms at York start late, but not quite late enough to spend a while at the country's biggest film festival, which finishes in a few days time

The Churchill Hotel

There is simply no argument strong enough to dispute the well established fact that student eating habits fall into one of two categories; student cooking or takeaways. Take your pick (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Sam Newsome)

Wine

After the undeniably delightful debauchery of Freshers' Week, the Week Three grim can hit even the hardiest of freshers

Pub

Let's start with the bad news. The House of Trembling Madness, on Stonegate, is not somewhere to save the pennies. There's no way to get round the fact that it's PS3.50 a pint across the board here, but telling you that now means the only way is up from here (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Sam Newsome)

Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps

Like <em>Platoon</em> that was released the year before it, I like Oliver Stone's <em>Wall Street </em>not just for its political and social relevance, but because of its enjoyable simplicity

Medea

Frayja Winterson's Medea is a personal and powerful interpretation

Barn Backstage: Medea (Week 2)

Mia de Graaf interviews Emily Thommes and Freyja Winterson, the joint directors of Medea in the Drama Barn, Friday - Sunday, Week 2.

Mr Nice

Howard Marks must be rubbing his hands with glee; not many criminals manage to have so much control over their own legacy, at least not without seeming repugnant in some way (last year's biopic of Charles Bronson comes to mind)

Rebel, Rebel

Controversial choreographer Michael Clark has reinvented just about every aspect of ballet. Mia de Graaf hears his take on the freedom of creativity (Thumbnail credit Michael Clark. All photos credit: Jake Walters)

Freshers' Food Diary

Contrary to your tutor's beliefs, man cannot live on knowledge alone. Here are some tried and tested student recipies lovingly collected by <em>Nouse</em>'s expert chefs for your benefit alone

Peter Iveson

A house game of Monopoly. A great chance to play a game properly, as being an only child and having to play by yourself soon loses its appeal (Thumbnail credit Justyn Hardcastle)

Social pariah: Charlotte Hogarth-Jones

Sainsburys pharmacy. I ask to speak to a 'medical advisor', as helpfully suggested by a laminated sign on the counter (Thumbnail credit Sam Newsome)

Camilla Jenkins

One of the advantages of York starting ridiculously late is that we have a good, long time to get used to that back-to-school feeling

Freshers by numbers

Freshers by numbers

MUSE: 12 October 2010

Welcome, first years to <em>Nouse</em>'s official Freshers' Guide. We have toiled through the nights, burning the midnight oil and depriving ourselves of sunlight to ensure that you are as prepared as possible for the adventures to come (Thumbnail credit George Lowther)

Lectures? What lectures?

It turns out UCAS may not have been entirely truthful about the whole university experience. Liv Evans offers a survival guide for the bemused, confused and slightly misused (Thumbnail credit George Lowther)

How to be indispensable

Ladies and gentlemen, intern and job applications are officially open. As we face one of the most competitive employment markets yet, India Richards investigates the best way to succeed during internships

A Nouse Night Out

By James Bithell

<em>Nouse</em>'s guide to a night out in York

Terry Waite: a man in the firing line

By James Bithell
